question: It is true that virtual memory allows a computer to use hard disk space as extra RAM when the actual RAM is full.
It is false that virtual memory helps by adding more physical RAM to the system.
It is true that in paging, RAM is divided into fixed-size blocks called frames, and processes are divided into small fixed-size blocks called pages.
It is false that paging causes external fragmentation, as it divides memory into fixed-size blocks.
It is true that segmentation divides memory into logical sections like code, data, and stack.
It is false that segmentation leads to internal fragmentation, as it uses logical sections with different sizes.
It is true that internal fragmentation occurs in paging when a process is allocated more space than it needs.
It is false that external fragmentation happens in paging, as it only uses fixed-size memory blocks.
It is true that a page fault occurs when a program requests data that is not in RAM but is stored in virtual memory (hard disk).
It is false that a minor page fault occurs when a page is not in RAM and needs to be loaded from the disk.
